title: ABC News: Vaccine access, not hesitancy, still a problem for Latinos
description: The pandemic has disproportionately affected the Latino community in a variety of ways. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Latinos are twice as likely to contract the virus as white adults are and 2.3 times more likely to die from it. A group of Latino senators sent a letter to the Biden administration Friday, urging top officials to improve access to COVID-19 vaccines in Latino communities. Jorge Caballero, MD, Stanford Medicine anesthesiologist and co-founder of the group Coders Against COVID, provides comment.

Stanford Health Care in the News May 28, 2021 The pandemic has disproportionately affected the Latino community in a variety of ways. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Latinos are twice as likely to contract the virus as white adults are and 2.3 times more likely to die from it. A group of Latino senators sent a letter to the Biden administration Friday, urging top officials to improve access to COVID-19 vaccines in Latino communities. [Jorge Caballero, MD](https://stanfordhealthcare.org/doctors/c/jorge-caballero.html), Stanford Medicine anesthesiologist and co-founder of the group Coders Against COVID, provides comment.
